column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=The present invention relates to the art of in vivo bone treatment.
#Text=It finds particular application to in vivo bone transport and lengthening and will be described with particular reference thereto.
#Text=Intercalary defects in long bones may occur as a result of trauma, resection necessitated by tumors or infection, or acute limb lengthening.
#Text=With appropriate mechanical fixation, these defects may be managed by autogenous bone grafting, segmental allograft reconstruction, or reconstruction using endoprostheses.
#Text=Autogenous bone grafting has the disadvantage of donor site morbidity including pain, increased blood loss, and surgical scarring.
#Text=Furthermore, in the case of large defects it may be difficult or impossible to obtain an optimal volume of autogenous bone.
#Text=While allografting eliminates the problem of adequate quantity, the incidence of complications such as infection, fracture, and non-union is increased.
#Text=The risk of exposure to HIV or hepatitis is another concern, raised by the use of allogenous material, bone or transfusion blood to treat bleeding.
#Text=In 1954, Ilizarov reported that mature bone can be elongated by gradual distraction of a fracture callus and called this process distraction osteogenesis.
#Text=The application of this technique in the form of bone segment transport or gradual bone lengthening can obviate the need for open bone grafting in many large diaphyseal defects.
#Text=Ilizarov used external fixation, with wires passing through the limb and bone, and connected to the external frame.

#Text=However, transfixing wires used in this technique can cause significant complications including wire site infection, bone infection, pain, scarring, and restricted joint motion due to the transfixation of tendons and muscles.
#Text=These complications are particularly relevant when the Ilizarov device is applied to the femur.
#Text=In 1990, Brunner reported that distraction osteogenesis was achievable using intramedullary fixation in sheep tibiae.
#Text=Brunner's method still relied on the use of an external fixator to provide the force necessary for bone transport.
#Text=Brunner's work implied that transfixing wires used for internal fixation could potentially be eliminated.
#Text=Betz described the use of a telescoping intramedullary rod for distraction osteogenesis.
#Text=With the Betz device, the patient apparently turned a small knob that protruded from the patient's hip in order to telescopically move the parts relative to one another.
